title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text: This document provides a comprehensive reference of all R commands used in Time Series Analysis practicals, organized by topic with brief descriptions and example usage.

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
2.1 Loading Built-in Datasets
# Load a built-in time series dataset
data("nottem")              # Average temperatures at Nottingham Castle
data("AirPassengers")       # Monthly airline passenger numbers
data("EuStockMarkets")      # European stock market indices
Description: The data() function loads built-in datasets from R or installed packages into the workspace.

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
2.2 Basic Time Series Information
# Get start year/month of time series
start(nottem)               # Returns: c(1920, 1) for Jan 1920

# Get end year/month of time series
end(nottem)                 # Returns: c(1939, 12) for Dec 1939

# Get frequency (observations per year)
frequency(nottem)           # Returns: 12 (monthly data)

# Get total number of observations
length(nottem)              # Returns: 240

# Get time index
time(nottem)                # Returns decimal years (1920.000, 1920.083, ...)
Description: These functions extract metadata about time series objects, essential for understanding data structure.

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
2.3 Summary Statistics
# Calculate mean
mean(nottem)                # Average value across all observations

# Calculate standard deviation
sd(nottem)                  # Measure of variability

# Find minimum value
min(nottem)                 # Lowest temperature recorded

# Find maximum value
max(nottem)                 # Highest temperature recorded

# Get range (min and max)
range(nottem)               # Returns: c(min, max)

# Summary statistics
summary(nottem)             # Min, Q1, Median, Mean, Q3, Max
Description: Basic statistical measures to understand central tendency and spread of the data.

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
3.1 ts() Function
# Create annual time series (frequency = 1)
rainfall_ts <- ts(data_vector, 
                  start = 1990, 
                  end = 2020, 
                  frequency = 1)

# Create monthly time series (frequency = 12)
monthly_ts <- ts(data_vector, 
                 start = c(2016, 1),  # January 2016
                 frequency = 12)

# Create quarterly time series (frequency = 4)
quarterly_ts <- ts(data_vector, 
                   start = c(2020, 1),  # Q1 2020
                   frequency = 4)
Description: The ts() function converts a numeric vector into a time series object with specified temporal structure.
Parameters: - data: Numeric vector of observations - start: Starting time (year or c(year, period)) - end: Ending time (optional if start and frequency specified) - frequency: Number of observations per year (1=annual, 4=quarterly, 12=monthly)

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
4.1 Basic Plotting
# Simple time series plot
plot(nottem)

# Customized plot with parameters
plot(nottem,
     main = "Average Air Temperatures",     # Title
     xlab = "Year",                          # X-axis label
     ylab = "Temperature (°F)",              # Y-axis label
     col = "blue",                           # Line color
     lwd = 2,                                # Line width
     type = "l")                             # Line type ("l"=line, "p"=points, "o"=both)

# Add grid lines
grid()

# Add horizontal line
abline(h = mean(nottem), col = "red", lty = 2)  # lty = line type (2=dashed)

# Add vertical line
abline(v = 1930, col = "green", lty = 3)

# Add regression line
abline(lm(nottem ~ time(nottem)), col = "red")
Description: plot() creates visualizations; abline() adds reference lines; grid() adds gridlines.

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
4.2 Multiple Plots
# Set up 2x1 plot layout
par(mfrow = c(2, 1))

plot(nottem)
plot(AirPassengers)

# Reset to single plot
par(mfrow = c(1, 1))

# Adjust margins: c(bottom, left, top, right)
par(mar = c(4, 4, 3, 2))
Description: par() sets graphical parameters, including multi-panel layouts and margins.

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
4.3 Histograms
# Basic histogram
hist(nottem)

# Customized histogram
hist(residuals,
     breaks = 20,                    # Number of bins
     main = "Histogram of Residuals",
     xlab = "Residuals",
     col = "lightblue",
     border = "black",
     probability = TRUE)             # Density instead of frequency
Description: hist() creates frequency or density histograms for data distribution analysis.

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
4.4 Q-Q Plots
# Normal Q-Q plot
qqnorm(residuals, 
       main = "Q-Q Plot",
       col = "blue", 
       pch = 19)        # Point character (19 = solid circle)

# Add reference line
qqline(residuals, col = "red", lwd = 2)
Description: qqnorm() creates quantile-quantile plots to assess normality; qqline() adds theoretical normal line.

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
5.1 decompose() Function
# Additive decomposition (default)
nottem_decomp <- decompose(nottem, type = "additive")

# Multiplicative decomposition
air_decomp <- decompose(AirPassengers, type = "multiplicative")

# Plot decomposition
plot(nottem_decomp)
Description: decompose() separates time series into trend, seasonal, and random components.
Types: - Additive: Y = Trend + Seasonal + Random (constant seasonal amplitude) - Multiplicative: Y = Trend × Seasonal × Random (proportional seasonal amplitude)

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
5.2 Extracting Components
# Extract individual components
trend <- nottem_decomp$trend           # Trend component
seasonal <- nottem_decomp$seasonal     # Seasonal component
random <- nottem_decomp$random         # Random/irregular component
observed <- nottem_decomp$x            # Original series
Description: Components can be extracted using $ operator for separate analysis.

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
6.1 Augmented Dickey-Fuller (ADF) Test
# Load tseries package
library(tseries)

# Perform ADF test
adf_result <- adf.test(nottem)

# Access results
adf_result$statistic          # Test statistic
adf_result$p.value            # P-value
adf_result$parameter          # Lag order
Description: Tests null hypothesis that series has unit root (non-stationary). - H₀: Series is non-stationary (has unit root) - H₁: Series is stationary - Reject H₀ if: p-value < 0.05

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
6.2 KPSS Test
# Perform KPSS test
kpss_result <- kpss.test(nottem)

# Access results
kpss_result$statistic         # Test statistic
kpss_result$p.value           # P-value
Description: Tests null hypothesis that series is stationary (opposite of ADF). - H₀: Series is stationary - H₁: Series is non-stationary - Reject H₀ if: p-value < 0.05

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
6.3 Phillips-Perron Test
# Perform PP test
pp_result <- PP.test(AirPassengers)
Description: Alternative unit root test, robust to heteroscedasticity and serial correlation.

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
7.1 First Differencing
# First difference: Y_t - Y_{t-1}
diff1 <- diff(nottem, differences = 1)

# Or simply
diff1 <- diff(nottem)
Description: Removes linear trend by computing consecutive differences.

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
7.2 Seasonal Differencing
# Seasonal difference (lag = frequency)
seasonal_diff <- diff(nottem, lag = 12)

# Combined: First + Seasonal differencing
combined_diff <- diff(diff(nottem), lag = 12)
Description: Removes seasonal patterns by differencing at seasonal lag (e.g., 12 for monthly data).

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
7.3 Log Transformation
# Natural logarithm transformation
log_series <- log(AirPassengers)

# Difference of log (returns/growth rates)
log_diff <- diff(log(AirPassengers))
Description: Stabilizes variance and converts multiplicative to additive relationships.

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
9.1 ACF (Autocorrelation Function)
# Calculate and plot ACF
acf_result <- acf(nottem,
                  lag.max = 40,      # Maximum lag to compute
                  main = "ACF Plot",
                  col = "blue",
                  lwd = 2)

# Access ACF values
acf_values <- acf_result$acf         # ACF coefficients
Description: Measures correlation between series and its lagged values. Used to identify MA order.
Interpretation: - Cuts off sharply: Suggests MA(q) process - Decays gradually: Suggests AR component

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
9.2 PACF (Partial Autocorrelation Function)
# Calculate and plot PACF
pacf_result <- pacf(nottem,
                    lag.max = 40,
                    main = "PACF Plot",
                    col = "red",
                    lwd = 2)

# Access PACF values
pacf_values <- pacf_result$acf
Description: Measures correlation between series and its lagged values, controlling for intermediate lags. Used to identify AR order.
Interpretation: - Cuts off sharply: Suggests AR(p) process - Decays gradually: Suggests MA component

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
10.1 arima() Function
# Load forecast package
library(forecast)

# Fit AR(1) model
ar1_model <- arima(nottem, order = c(1, 0, 0))

# Fit MA(1) model
ma1_model <- arima(nottem, order = c(0, 0, 1))

# Fit ARMA(1,1) model
arma11_model <- arima(nottem, order = c(1, 0, 1))

# Fit ARIMA(1,1,1) model with differencing
arima111_model <- arima(nottem, order = c(1, 1, 1))

# Fit Seasonal ARIMA
sarima_model <- arima(nottem, 
                      order = c(1, 0, 1),        # (p, d, q)
                      seasonal = list(order = c(1, 1, 1),  # (P, D, Q)
                                      period = 12))        # Seasonal period
Description: Fits ARIMA models with specified orders.
Parameters: - p: AR (autoregressive) order - d: Differencing order - q: MA (moving average) order - P: Seasonal AR order - D: Seasonal differencing order - Q: Seasonal MA order

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
10.2 auto.arima() Function
# Automatic model selection
auto_model <- auto.arima(nottem,
                         seasonal = TRUE,       # Include seasonal component
                         stepwise = FALSE,      # Exhaustive search
                         approximation = FALSE, # Use exact likelihood
                         trace = TRUE)          # Print search progress
Description: Automatically selects best ARIMA model using AIC/BIC criteria.

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
10.3 Model Coefficients
# Get model coefficients
coef(model)

# Get coefficient standard errors
sqrt(diag(vcov(model)))

# Get variance-covariance matrix
vcov(model)

# Model summary
summary(model)
Description: Extract parameter estimates and uncertainty measures from fitted models.

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
11.1 ets() Function
# Automatic ETS model selection
ets_model <- ets(nottem)

# Specify model components
ets_model <- ets(AirPassengers,
                 model = "MAM")    # Multiplicative error, Additive trend, Multiplicative seasonal

# ETS model types:
# "ZZZ" = Automatic selection
# "ANN" = Additive error, No trend, No seasonal
# "AAN" = Additive error, Additive trend, No seasonal
# "AAA" = Additive error, Additive trend, Additive seasonal
# "MAM" = Multiplicative error, Additive trend, Multiplicative seasonal
Description: Fits exponential smoothing state space models (Error-Trend-Seasonal framework).

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
12.1 Residual Analysis
# Extract residuals
residuals <- residuals(model)

# Standardized residuals
std_residuals <- residuals / sqrt(model$sigma2)

# Residual statistics
mean(residuals)                 # Should be ~0
sd(residuals)                   # Residual standard deviation
Description: Residuals should behave like white noise for adequate models.

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
12.2 Box-Pierce Test
# Box-Pierce test for autocorrelation
bp_test <- Box.test(residuals, 
                    lag = 20, 
                    type = "Box-Pierce")

bp_test$p.value
Description: Tests null hypothesis that residuals are uncorrelated (white noise). - H₀: No autocorrelation - p-value > 0.05: Fail to reject (good - residuals are white noise)

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
12.3 Ljung-Box Test
# Ljung-Box test (more powerful than Box-Pierce)
lb_test <- Box.test(residuals, 
                    lag = 20, 
                    type = "Ljung-Box",
                    fitdf = length(coef(model)))  # Degrees of freedom

lb_test$statistic
lb_test$p.value
Description: Tests for autocorrelation in residuals; preferred over Box-Pierce test.

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
12.4 Shapiro-Wilk Normality Test
# Test for normality of residuals
shapiro_test <- shapiro.test(residuals)

shapiro_test$statistic          # W statistic
shapiro_test$p.value            # P-value
Description: Tests null hypothesis that data comes from normal distribution. - H₀: Data is normally distributed - p-value > 0.05: Fail to reject (residuals are normal)

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
12.5 Jarque-Bera Test
# Load tseries package
library(tseries)

# Jarque-Bera test for normality
jb_test <- jarque.bera.test(residuals)
Description: Alternative normality test based on skewness and kurtosis.

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
12.6 Variance Test
# F-test for equality of variances
var_test <- var.test(residuals_1, residuals_2)

var_test$statistic              # F-statistic
var_test$p.value                # P-value
Description: Tests whether two groups have equal variance (homoscedasticity).

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
13.1 Information Criteria
# Akaike Information Criterion
AIC(model)

# Bayesian Information Criterion
BIC(model)

# Log-likelihood
logLik(model)

# Number of parameters
length(coef(model))

# Residual variance
model$sigma2
Description: Lower AIC/BIC indicates better model fit with parsimony penalty.
Formula: - AIC: -2 × log-likelihood + 2k (k = number of parameters) - BIC: -2 × log-likelihood + k × log(n) (n = sample size)

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
13.2 Model Comparison
# Compare multiple models
models <- list(
  "AR(1)" = ar1_model,
  "MA(1)" = ma1_model,
  "ARMA(1,1)" = arma11_model
)

# Extract AIC for all models
sapply(models, AIC)

# Extract BIC for all models
sapply(models, BIC)

# Find best model
best_model <- names(models)[which.min(sapply(models, AIC))]
Description: Systematic comparison of competing models using information criteria.

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
14.1 forecast() Function
# Generate forecast
forecast_result <- forecast(model, h = 12)  # h = forecast horizon

# Access forecast components
forecast_result$mean            # Point forecasts
forecast_result$lower           # Lower prediction intervals
forecast_result$upper           # Upper prediction intervals

# Specific confidence level
forecast_result$lower[, "80%"]  # 80% lower bound
forecast_result$upper[, "95%"]  # 95% upper bound
Description: Produces forecasts with prediction intervals from fitted models.

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
14.2 Plot Forecast
# Plot forecast with prediction intervals
plot(forecast_result,
     main = "Forecast",
     xlab = "Time",
     ylab = "Value",
     col = "blue",
     lwd = 2,
     shadecols = c("lightblue", "lightgray"))  # PI colors
Description: Visualizes historical data, forecasts, and uncertainty bands.

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
15.1 Skewness and Kurtosis
# Install moments package if needed
# install.packages("moments")

# Load moments package (optional)
if (requireNamespace("moments", quietly = TRUE)) {
  library(moments)
  
  # Calculate skewness
  skewness(residuals)
  
  # Calculate kurtosis
  kurtosis(residuals)
}
Description: Measures distribution shape. - Skewness = 0: Symmetric - Kurtosis = 3: Normal distribution

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
15.2 Linear Regression
# Fit linear model
lm_model <- lm(y ~ x)

# With time trend
trend_model <- lm(series ~ time(series))

# Get fitted values
fitted(trend_model)

# Get residuals
residuals(trend_model)

# Model summary
summary(trend_model)

# Extract coefficients
coef(trend_model)
Description: lm() fits linear regression models, useful for trend estimation.

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
16.1 Subsetting Time Series
# Extract specific time window
window(nottem, start = c(1920, 1), end = c(1925, 12))

# Extract by index
nottem[1:12]                    # First 12 observations

# Split into periods
first_half <- nottem[1:(length(nottem)/2)]
second_half <- nottem[(length(nottem)/2 + 1):length(nottem)]
Description: window() extracts time series subsets preserving temporal structure.

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
16.2 Combining Time Series
# Combine multiple time series
cbind(series1, series2, series3)

# Row-wise combination
rbind(series1, series2)
Description: Combine time series objects into multivariate structures.

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
17.1 Printing
# Print with cat()
cat("AIC:", round(AIC(model), 2), "\n")

# Print formatted strings
sprintf("The p-value is %.4f", p_value)

# Print separator lines
cat(paste(rep("=", 50), collapse = ""), "\n")
cat(paste(rep("-", 50), collapse = ""), "\n")
Description: cat() prints output; sprintf() formats strings; paste() concatenates.

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
17.2 Rounding
# Round to n decimal places
round(3.14159, 2)               # Returns: 3.14

# Round multiple values
round(c(1.234, 5.678), 1)       # Returns: c(1.2, 5.7)
Description: round() rounds numeric values to specified decimal places.

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
17.3 Tables with kable()
# Load knitr package
library(knitr)

# Create formatted table
kable(data_frame,
      digits = 2,                           # Decimal places
      caption = "Model Comparison",         # Table caption
      col.names = c("Model", "AIC", "BIC"), # Column names
      align = c("l", "r", "r"))             # Alignment (l=left, r=right, c=center)
Description: Creates formatted tables for Quarto/RMarkdown documents.

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
18.2 Essential Packages
# Time series analysis
library(tseries)        # Stationarity tests, GARCH models
library(forecast)       # ARIMA, ETS, forecasting
library(zoo)            # Rolling statistics, irregular time series
library(xts)            # Extended time series

# Visualization
library(ggplot2)        # Advanced graphics

# Diagnostics
library(lmtest)         # Linear model tests

# Tables
library(knitr)          # kable() for tables
Description: Core packages for time series analysis in R.

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
21.1 Check Stationarity
# Both tests should agree
adf_test <- adf.test(series)
kpss_test <- kpss.test(series)

is_stationary <- (adf_test$p.value < 0.05) & (kpss_test$p.value >= 0.05)

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
21.2 Extract Significant Lags
# From ACF/PACF
acf_result <- acf(series, plot = FALSE)
conf_level <- qnorm(0.975) / sqrt(length(series))
significant_lags <- which(abs(acf_result$acf) > conf_level)

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
21.3 Model Adequacy Check
# Comprehensive diagnostic
residuals <- residuals(model)

# 1. White noise
lb_test <- Box.test(residuals, lag = 20, type = "Ljung-Box")

# 2. Normality
shapiro_test <- shapiro.test(residuals)

# 3. Constant variance
plot(residuals)
abline(h = 0, col = "red")

# Model is adequate if:
# - lb_test$p.value > 0.05 (white noise)
# - shapiro_test$p.value > 0.05 (normal)
# - residual plot shows constant variance

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
22.1 1. Always Visualize First
plot(series)  # Look before you leap!

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
22.2 2. Test Stationarity
# Use both tests for confirmation
adf.test(series)
kpss.test(series)

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
22.3 3. Transform if Needed
# Log for variance stabilization
log(series)

# Difference for stationarity
diff(series)

# Both
diff(log(series))

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
22.4 4. Check Residuals Thoroughly
# Multiple diagnostic plots
par(mfrow = c(2, 2))
plot(residuals)
hist(residuals)
acf(residuals)
qqnorm(residuals); qqline(residuals)
par(mfrow = c(1, 1))

title: Time Series Analysis - R Commands Reference
text:
22.5 5. Compare Multiple Models
# Never rely on a single model
models <- list(
  arima(series, c(1,1,1)),
  arima(series, c(2,1,1)),
  auto.arima(series)
)
sapply(models, AIC)
